articles.title: Gunshots halt July 4th parade in Chicago suburb. Hear witness describe scene  - CNN Video
articles.description: Witness Miles Zaremski describes the moment he heard gunshots in downtown Highland Park, Illinois, during the local July 4th parade.

articles.title: Watch CNN Live coverage of Highland Park shooting
articles.description: Stream CNN TV from the US for free with your TV service provider account.

articles.author: By Aditi Sangal, Elise Hammond, Maureen Chowdhury and Mike Hayes, CNN
articles.title: Live updates: Police responding to shooting at July 4th parade in Illinois
articles.description: Police are responding to a shooting in downtown Highland Park, Illinois, in the area of a July 4th parade, authorities said. Follow here for the latest news updates.
articles.content:
Miles Zaremski, a Highland Park, Illinois, resident, told CNN he was walking to the Fourth of July parade when he heard a "pop" and thought that maybe a car backfired. 
"And then there were multiple… [+627 chars]

articles.title: What we know about the fatal police shooting of Jayland Walker
articles.description: The city of Akron, Ohio, is on edge this Fourth of July, one week after the fatal police shooting of 25-year-old Jayland Walker.

articles.author: Eric Levenson, Shawn Nottingham
articles.title: Shooting at Fourth of July parade in Highland Park, Illinois, leaves at least 5 dead, 16 wounded, city says
articles.description: A mass shooting at a Fourth of July parade Monday in a wealthy suburb outside Chicago, Illinois, left at least five people dead and 16 wounded, according to the city of Highland Park.
articles.content:

articles.title: Americans divided over what US stands for on this July Fourth
articles.description: Rarely have Americans been so divided on what their country stands for as on the 246th anniversary of independence.
articles.content:

articles.author: Kevin Liptak
articles.title: Cheney says January 6 committee could make multiple criminal referrals, including of Trump
articles.description: The House select committee investigating the January 6 insurrection could make multiple criminal referrals, including of former President Donald Trump, the panel's vice chair, Rep. Liz Cheney, said in an interview broadcast Sunday.
